description:
Pseudoliparis swirei is a species of snailfish that inhabits the deep waters of the Mariana Trench, the deepest part of the world's oceans. This species was first discovered and described in 2017, making it one of the most recently discovered fish species.

Pseudoliparis swirei is a small, gelatinous fish, typically measuring around 6-8 centimeters in length. It has a flattened, disc-like body and a large, gaping mouth, which is a common adaptation among deep-sea fishes to help them capture prey in the dimly lit, high-pressure environments they inhabit.

The species is named after retired U.S. Navy Captain and oceanographer, Victor Swiridoff, who contributed significantly to the exploration and understanding of the Mariana Trench ecosystem.

Pseudoliparis swirei is believed to feed on small crustaceans and other invertebrates found in the deep-sea environment. Its gelatinous body and unique physiological adaptations, such as the ability to withstand the extreme pressure of the Mariana Trench, make it a fascinating subject of study for scientists interested in the unique biodiversity of the deepest parts of the world's oceans.
